2 CV 2.1 3rd year Projecticum Biomolecular Research A six months project in which research was conducted into the identification of several fresh water fish using qPCR-MCA techniques. In collaboration with Aquon. Projecticum Data Science 2.1.1 Theoretical courses Biotechnology Advanced Labtools Tumorcell Biology 2.1.2 Practical courses Project Molecular Biology Construction of a vector using the glucocorticoid receptor gene and pEGFP-Nx plasmid, consequently transforming this vector into E.coli cells, after which a colony PCR was done and the vector transfected into HEK293 cells. The cloning of the construct was validated by SDS-Page and Western Blot. 2.2 Honours projects (extracurricular) Transfection of HEK293 cells through replicative transposon integration for continues MPTX1 gene expression Intra-individual differences and effects of temperature on ɑ-amylase activity 2.3 2nd year 2.3.1 Theoretical courses Zoological research & Pharmacology Immunology Molecular Biology Metabolism and muscle physiology Physiological regulation systems 2.3.2 Practical courses Project Genes & Proteins ELISA, Differential centrifugation, SDS-Page and Western blot, Liquid Chromatography (Äkta-prime) Project Pharmacon Research into the effect of the active ingredient in cannabis, CBD, on Alzheimer in C.elegans (CL4176). 2.4 Extracurricular courses Data Science for Biology 2.5 Work Experience Laboratory assistent, Nutricontrol June 2024 - present Projectmanagement Office Consultant, Tafelberg Advies Oktober 2022 - July 2024 2.6 Internship DiMicheleLAB, Cambridge Under supervision of Lorenzo Di Michele To aim of this project is to add an important new functionality to the RNA-MLOs, namely the ability to act as microreactors that promote chemical reactions to occur with increased rates and specificity. Initial studies have demonstrated that enzymes such as Glucose Oxidase (GOx) and Horseradish Peroxidase (HRP) show increased catalytic activity for glucose and hydrogen peroxide oxidation, respectively, when colocalised within these constructs. This increase reaction rate extends to coupled catalytic cascade systems comprising both enzymes. The project will further seek to fine-tune reaction control by adjusting the enzyme-to-substrate ratio, tuning the ratio between both enzymes in a coupled catalytic system inside a bi-phasic RNA-MLOs system, and to explore how enzyme colocalisation within RNA-MLOs affects the catalytic activity of different enzymes, including Alkaline Phosphatase, Adenylate Kinase, and Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase.
3 Free Space: Visualisation of scRNA sequencing using Python 3.1 scRNA sequencing using Python

3 Free Space: Visualisation of scRNA sequencing using Python The goal of the free space is to develop skills that are not discussed in this course. Dit biedt veel vrijheid en daarnaast ook de ruimte om jezelf te ontwikkelen in de richting van een latere baan. 3.1 scRNA sequencing using Python In februari zal ik stage lopen bij de DiMicheleLAB, in cambridge. In onze gesprekken hebben zij laten weten dat ik python zal gebruiken bij het verwerken van de data die ik in mijn stage zal krijgen. Ik wil daarom deze vrije ruimte gebruiken om mij alvast te verdiepen in het gebruiken van de programmeertaal Python. Wanneer ik zoek op veelgebruikte analyses met Python, komt hier al snel singlecell RNA sequencing naar boven. Echter is het niet mogelijk om in de korte tijd, 32 uur, de hele workflow van de scRNA sequencing te leren. Ik ga me daarom focussen op de visualisatie van de data met behulp van Python.

5 Exercises 5.1 Opdracht 3.2 You are requested to run an analysis on the raw data in this file (sheet named ‘All Cycles’). It contains data from a plate reader experiment where wells are measured over time. The researcher asks you to generate a plot per sample. No other information was provided in the original email. Describe the following steps in an RMarkdown file. You do not need to write the R code for the actual analysis at this point - we will do that later in another exercise in this lesson. Answer these questions in your markdown file with exercises. 1. How would you prepare for this analysis in R/Rstudio? 2. Look at the contents of the file, which Excel Worksheet do you need for the analysis? De eerste sheet. Hier staat de ruwe data van de plate reader. 3. Which steps do you need to take to load the data into R Inladen van de eerste sheet van de data in een variabele. Which steps do you need to take in reshaping the file to make the dataformat match the requirement for using `{ggplot} Pivot longer zodat de tijd een eigen kolom heeft Groeperen Plotten Think of a better file name 8_10_2024_OD600_ipsc Write a conceptual and kind and friendly, but clear reply email (in English) to the researcher, where you address the changes that the researcher needs to make to the file in order for you to be able to analyze this data in R. 5.2 Exercise 3.3 ## Dit is de codering voor 1 bestand, maar om herhaling van code te voorkomen, gaan we dit anders schrijven. library(tools) library(here) ## here() starts at /Users/annemariekekreeft/school/dsfb2_workflows_portfolio library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(dplyr) library(tibble) library(readr) md5_ex1_raw <- tools::md5sum( here::here( "opdrachten", "md5_examples", "MD5_exampledata_1.txt" ) ) #1. Specify directory myDir <- here::here( "opdrachten", "md5_examples") #2. Specify file names fileNames <- list.files(myDir, recursive = TRUE) #3 md5sum met path naar dir en filenames. dit wordt net als hiervoor enframed(). tools::md5sum(file.path(myDir, fileNames)) %>% enframe() -> md5sums_all #4. We willen ook fileNames toevoegen md5sums_all$filename<- fileNames #5. Alle relevante informatie staat eigenlijk in filename en value. Dus, select om alleen deze te laten zien. md5sums_all %>% select(filename, value) ## # A tibble: 4 × 2 ## filename value ## <chr> <chr> ## 1 MD5_exampledata_1.txt f3d2eeb79b4c24490bf08f483e5cadd3 ## 2 MD5_exampledata_backupcomputercrash.txt f3d2eeb79b4c24490bf08f483e5cadd3 ## 3 MD5_exampledata_maybethisone.txt a331f23fd3586f0100173bd28b1e319c ## 4 MD5_exampledata_savethisone.txt f3d2eeb79b4c24490bf08f483e5cadd3 5.3 Exercise 3.4 A. Determine the md5sums of the file. Save the checksums to a file [write a piece of R code] ex4_raw <- tools::md5sum( here::here( "opdrachten", "toxrefdb_nel_lel_noael_loael_summary_AUG2014_FOR_PUBLIC_RELEASE.csv" ) ) %>% enframe() -> ex4_toxref ex4_toxref$value ## [1] "399276ed77401f350aaee0c52400c5e9" B. Upload the file to the Rstudio server and check again. Again, save the resulting md5sums in a file. Do the md5sums you calculated on the server and the md5sums of the local file match? # On the Rstudio Server: ex4_raw <- tools::md5sum( here::here( "dsfb2", "toxrefdb_nel_lel_noael_loael_summary_AUG2014_FOR_PUBLIC_RELEASE.csv" ) ) %>% enframe() -> ex4_toxref_check “399276ed77401f350aaee0c52400c5e9” Yes, the files match. C. Download the md5 file you just generated on the server (or upload the one you generated locally). Can you think of a way to check in an R script whether they are the same? Write the script and save it in a .R file ex4_raw <- tools::md5sum( here::here( "opdrachten", "toxrefdb_nel_lel_noael_loael_summary_AUG2014_FOR_PUBLIC_RELEASE.csv" ) ) %>% enframe() -> ex4_toxref ex4_toxref$value ## [1] "399276ed77401f350aaee0c52400c5e9" ex4_raw2 <- tools::md5sum( here::here( "opdrachten", "toxrefdb_nel_lel_noael_loael_summary_AUG2014_FOR_PUBLIC_RELEASE_server.csv" ) ) %>% enframe() -> ex4_toxref2 ex4_toxref$value ## [1] "399276ed77401f350aaee0c52400c5e9" ex4_toxref$value == ex4_toxref$value ## [1] TRUE library("fs") fs::dir_tree(here::here("opdrachten")) ## /Users/annemariekekreeft/school/dsfb2_workflows_portfolio/opdrachten ## ├── 01-introduction.Rmd ## ├── 03-freespace.Rmd ## ├── CV_Annemarieke_Kreeft.pdf ## ├── covid_data.Rmd ## ├── md5_examples ## │ ├── MD5_exampledata_1.txt ## │ ├── MD5_exampledata_backupcomputercrash.txt ## │ ├── MD5_exampledata_maybethisone.txt ## │ └── MD5_exampledata_savethisone.txt ## ├── portfolio_annemarieke.Rmd ## ├── toxrefdb_nel_lel_noael_loael_summary_AUG2014_FOR_PUBLIC_RELEASE.csv ## └── toxrefdb_nel_lel_noael_loael_summary_AUG2014_FOR_PUBLIC_RELEASE_server.csv
